Yes, losses can occur, but these deals are not exactly "collecting pennies in front of a steamroller".

2) SAAS Exposure

Of course, that is not all there is to the OWL news. The SAAS (software as a stop-loss, or something like that) exposure has gotten the attention of the market as well. We discussed this more in depth with the members of our service, and we won't go into all the points here. But suffice to say, we believe the odds of Claude doing a massive software displacement line up with what everyone believed about Upstart (UPST)'s "AI" and displacement of Fair Isaac Corporation (FICO) and their scores in 2021. From the peak of that insanity, here are the returns for both.

3) Redemption Halt

Yes OWL did stop redemptions on one of its funds.

While that may sound terrifying, not every asset has the liquidity of the US Treasury market. If you had a fund, which invested in Class A apartment buildings and you had to liquidate them, there is almost no way you could do that overnight without losing a lot of spread. Private credit is a far more complicated investment and anyone buying this debt of any single investment would have to do a lot of due diligence. It isn't really designed to be sold as needed for redemptions. Stopping the liquidation process is actually the best move and prevents unnecessary losses. If investors wanted the liquidity of public markets, well, they should have stayed in public markets. We think order will be restored down the line and let's keep in mind that even this fund makes up less than 1% of OWL's AUM.

Verdict

Yes, things might go bad for private credit at some point. If that is the argument and people want to stay away, that's ok. We think private credit is well-priced and designed for good returns. It is certainly beautifully priced relative to the S&P 500 (SPY). So we think this is a good time to invest a measured amount here. We did initiate OWL covered calls the other day and they have fairly attractive returns for a flattish price.

We also pointed out to our subscribers that the solid debt of OWL was trading at a near 7% yield to maturity. That is an interesting option for defensive investors as well. OWL's credit rating is excellent:

We have personally traded the bonds before, but this time we just went with covered calls as the return profile was much better.

Please note that this is not financial advice. It may seem like it sounds like it, but surprisingly, it is not. Investors are expected to do their own due diligence and consult a professional who knows their objectives and constraints. Most of our articles are not written for “buy and hold” investors. Our articles are not written for investors who ignore capital preservation while focusing only on yield.

data.title: Oil States International: Don't Trip Over That Hockey Stick!
data.description:
Introduction

You would think after 8 years of writing on this platform that I would have covered every company in the upstream space. Two or three times. Sadly, that's just not the case; new names still bubble up to the surface. In this outing, we add Oil States International (OIS) to the coverage universe.

Good golly, it's been a while since I've seen a hockey stick graph like the one below. The company has made a parabolic move higher, following its earnings release last week and after SCOTUS struck down Trump's use of IEEPA tariffs that had raised tariffs on some of their key products to 98%! And to continue with another 16% gain over a couple of days when most of the rest of the OSF category was giving back? That's intriguing, to say the least.

Oil States is a key supplier to the offshore rig market. When rigs are cranking, so too is OIS. The company graphic below gives you an idea of their spectrum of product offerings. You can certainly see the relationship to floating structures, even if the specific application doesn't mean a lot. We will go into a bit of detail on some of them a bit more a little later.

OIS is a market leader in several categories and has invested in new facilities in the UK and Indonesia that give it an advantage in an improving market. It is also introducing new technologies to replace older, land-based offerings that have seen declines along with the rig count.

The company turned in a big beat on EPS of $0.13 vs. $0.10 for Q4 2026, while missing on the topline by $454K. Analysts rate the company as an overweight with price targets as high as $15.00. The median is $13.50-where they trade now at the apogee of the parabola. This also constitutes a 5-year high for the stock, so we will tread carefully on this one.

The business case for Oil States

One sign that an increase in offshore activity is coming is the book-to-bill ratio for OIS. At 1.3X, it has reached the highest level in a decade. Much of this is from offshore rig upgrades and reactivations, but also from newer product offerings like their Managed Pressure Drilling—MPD, Perforating, and Mineral Riser. The company is optimistic they have turned a corner, particularly as regards international and offshore-related projects. While we agree that the offshore industry is on an upswing, it should also be noted there are capacity limits to this increase on the deepwater side. We have what we have in floating inventory, and no one is building new units. So it's ok to be optimistic-I am—but let's keep our feet on the ground. This is not 2005. There is no oil boom coming.

OIS has three primary operating segments: Offshore Manufactured Products, Completion and Production Services, and Downhole Technologies.

Cindy Taylor, CEO, commented about the upgrade cycle now underway-

We're beginning to see those white spaces, gaps be filled in. And so rig equipment will tend to lead the recovery, and that can be riser systems, MPD systems for us, the things that we offer as well as kind of the upgrade and service cycle around that equipment, but it all feeds deepwater infrastructure, which, again, that's kind of a bread and butter for us that plays into our more proprietary products.

Catalyst for Oil States

Have you ever tried to use a long pole-something 12-15' long—to wash off a spot on the eaves of your house? If you have, you likely experienced a problem common to landing out a marine riser thousands of feet below the rig floor-getting the thing to be in the position you need it to be in. Once you've overcome mechanical flexing, submarine currents, and the occasional shark (as you see below from a job I worked for BP in the GoM. Once we saw the shark, we suspended operations and allowed the critter to satisfy its curiosity. It took about half an hour, but he eventually swam away into the inky-it's really dark at 3,400 below MSL, depths and we got back to work.) That's curious about what you're doing, and you have it in a stabbing position-verified by your robotic camera flyby controlled by a tether from the rig's deck.

You want it to snap in cleanly and make the connection. Making a long story short, it doesn't always happen, and non-productive time-NPT results. Oil companies hate this and will reward companies that enable smooth operations with contracts. That appears to be the case with the OIS Flexjoint connector. The Flexjoint enables the riser to withstand currents and maintain its connection to the subsea BOP by flexing with the force. (You do not want to imagine the misery that follows an unplanned disconnect-it's bad, really bad.) Having this leading position in Flexjoint connectors is a distinct advantage for OIS.

Managed Pressure Drilling-MPD is an interesting growth area for OIS. The segment is well covered by legacy multi-service OFS companies-Big Red. Big Blue. Big Aqua and others. They don't give a lot of information about it in the filing but commented favorably on the early results in the conference call.

OIS also has offerings in perforating that appear to be gaining success-in a fairly crowded marketplace. Here again the big colors hold the biggest chunks of this business. The company cited international opportunities as driving their optimism in this area.

In summary, OIS is a legacy supplier to the offshore industry with an excellent reputation in their core offerings. When companies like Transocean (RIG) talk about upgrade and reactivation capex, they very often are talking about money that will end up on OIS' income statement. From my experience, I can tell that when a client trusts your core offerings, it makes it much easier to get field trials for new technology.

OIS Q4 Earning Call

OIS reported revenues of $178 million, up 8% sequentially from the third quarter. Profitability also improved with adjusted EBITDA of $23 million, representing a 9% sequential increase. Non-cash impairments on long-lived assets led to a loss of $117 mm. This was related to valuation declared on the 2018 acquisition in their Downhole Technology segment.

OIS generated 63% greater positive cash flow of $50 mm for the quarter than previously and 129% greater $105 mm for the year. Free cash of $94 mm was reported, a 92% rise YoY.

Their largest segment, Offshore Manufactured Products generated revenues of $123 million and EBITDA of $25 mm at a 20% margin. Backlog for this segment was reported at $435 mm. Completion Products turned in $23 mm in revenues and $7 mm in EBITDA with an operating margin of 32%. Restructuring charges of $5 mm were noted for the segment. Downhole Technologies reported revenues of $32 mm with EBITDA of $1.3 mm-impacted by segment impairments.

OIS has a new 4-year cash flow-based credit agreement, which provides for borrowings of up to $75 million. This is under a revolving credit facility that replaced their asset-based lending credit agreement. OIS has $53 million of convertible senior notes outstanding at December 31. The plan is to use U.S. cash on hand and tap their new revolver to retire these notes prior to their maturity on April 1, 2026.

At YE 2025, OIS had $15 mm in cash on hand, had retired $71 mm in senior notes during the year, and repurchased $17 mm in stock during 2025.

Guidance for 2026

OIS expects 2026 full-year revenues to range between $680 million and $700 million, up about 5% YoY. Full-year EBITDA should range between $90 million and $95 million, nearly double 2025. Q-1 should see revenues in a range of $150 million to $155 million and EBITDA of $18 million to $19 million.

Strong cash flows from operations are expected for the year. With a range of $60 million to $65 million, down from 2025 due to expected working capital builds. Investments in CapEx of $20 million to $25 million are planned for the year.

Company filings

Risks

The offshore comeback has been a bit of a 'fits and starts' operation over the past couple of years. Signs are that it is accelerating all around, but further delays could impact OIS revenues and cash flows. The parabolic move higher over the past few days is concerning, as it's related more to implied tariff relief than an improvement in core business fundamentals. We haven't had the last word on tariffs yet, so there may be other shoes to drop.

Your takeaway

I think a lot of near-term growth is priced into OIS at current levels. As shown below, the company is trading far in excess of its peer group's EV/EBITDA on a TTM basis. On an NTM basis, they are more reasonable at 7.77X if they hit their revenue and EBITDA targets of $700 mm and $95 mm respectively, so let's use those numbers to estimate a closer valuation for the shares. OIS has essentially no LT debt, so with 58 mm shares outstanding and $95 mm in EBITDA 7.77X, you get a share price of $12.72.

If I were long, I would sell at current levels to protect the substantial gains made over a very short period of time. Accordingly, I rate OIS a sell at current levels, in spite of their excellent prospects in the year to come. If they revert to their January 2026 levels of $7-8.00 per share, I would look hard at taking a position for measured growth that will surely come if the offshore renaissance becomes a reality.

data.title: Crescent Energy: A Royal Addition
data.description:
Crescent Energy (CRGY) has actually acquired significant midstream assets along the way. But now there is an obvious attempt to also gain royalty interests at a good price. Diversification into these two areas can help with company performance during cyclical downturns. Creating a separate royalty company as others have done can also help to finance transactions. It is yet another interest in production profits that can aid a lower breakeven.

In the meantime, the dominate upstream interests in the Eagle Ford and the Permian should provide above average profitability for a management that generally builds and sells companies. There are alot improvements to be made (as well be discussed in this article) that benefit royalties as well.

This is a management that pays a lot of attention to the cash flow statement. Not only should cash flow grow, but cash flow per share should grow as well. This company made 3 significant acquisitions in fiscal year 2025. That type of activity is going to make it very hard for investors to see the progress made for the properties already owned. It also makes the quarterly report next to useless.

However, as the company grows larger, the acquisitions will become less significant (as a percentage of the company). What should happen over time is that operational improvements will dominate. This is a company that will very likely be concentrating on cash flow and free cash flow.

Professionals that build companies know that cash generation is the key to getting a good price when the right time comes to sell the company. Right now, this company is clearly in buying mode. That should tell investors, that the industry overall is likely cheap (and out of favor). When management like this one decides to sell the company, that will be the time for most of us to consider cutting back our presence investing in oil and gas to wait for the next favorable time to get in.

Last Article

The last article noted that the company closed the acquisition of Vital Energy. The current announcement notes that Vital Energy was only part of the company for a few days of the quarter.

But that means that because of this rather significant acquisition, the company is going to be showing considerable production growth in the present fiscal year (2026).

Now that the company has acquired the assets, there is an update to the potential synergy savings. Fortunately, it is on the upward revisions side. More importantly, the rig activity has been sharply reduced.

As has been mentioned in many articles here, KKR is the manager of this company. Free cash flow is a very big deal to KKR. As the company gets larger and the financial statements are not clouded with lots of one-time items, this emphasis on free cash flow (growth) is likely to present itself first.

The Vital Energy acquisition was by far the largest acquisition of the fiscal year. At issue here is things like stock dilution (and debt) come first with the benefits likely showing in fiscal year 2026.

The company is showing investors where those benefits will come from. But this acquisition also provides the company with an entry into a second very low-cost basin.

At the same time, as part of a larger company, "in-housing" some of the operations that were contracted out is a very big deal. Vital Energy had begun some of the operational improvements noted above before the acquisition. But it had not owned much of the Permian properties itself for all that long.

As a much larger company (post combination) Crescent Energy is able to probably get better prices for the production than Vital could.

However, both companies had to live with existing production costs to some extent because the previous operators were likely high cost. Those high costs can be dealt with to some extent. But largely, that older production simply declines in significance as production declines. It will be replaced by lower cost production. But in terms of operating costs declining, that is a weighted average process that will take some time for the new lower well costs to gain significance.

Eagle Ford

The Eagle Ford assets have largely been a part of the company for a year. There was a large Eagle Ford acquisition of less than $1 billion that closed at the beginning of fiscal year 2025. That was really the only addition to these assets of a significant size.

This is the place where the savings will become apparent first because these assets are the oldest assets (for the most part) in the portfolio. This is also where most of the company production is presently. Future acquisitions could change that now that the company has a presence in the Permian.

Probably the biggest surprise is the natural gas position that is so close to export capability and may also be sold in the future to data centers as well. This was an upside that many of us did not see on the horizon at the time this company began operations. Now it is a big deal.

Debt

This company has received one debt rating upgrade since it went public. There is a goal here to get to investment grade.

As noted above, things are going to definitely improve because of that goal of an investment grade rating. If the improvements shown before (and probably a few more I did not show) actually materially improve things, then that will change the debt rating fraction numerator.

This company is also faster than most to sell noncore acreage to raise cash. Probably one of the best debt managers in the business is KKR. This is what is going to make the cash flow statement the most important statement in the future.

Summary

Crescent Energy did post a loss for the quarter as there was an impairment charge combined with a lot of transaction costs that were a part of the Vital Energy acquisition closing.

What as more important is that cash flow grew significantly for the fiscal year while the debt ratio stayed within range for the company to still go for an investment grade debt rating.

As long as this company is making acquisitions, that likely means that acquisition prices are attractive (and the industry remains relatively out of favor).

That makes this idea a long-term idea with the idea that the company will be built during times of attractive acquisition prices. It will be sold when prices are cyclically strong. But that means investors need to wait patiently for the time when selling prices are attractive enough to sell the company.

This is a strong buy idea in that rarely do investors get the chance to invest alongside KKR and John Goff. That does mean success is guaranteed. But it does put the odds in favor of the investment idea succeeding. This part has not changed since the company went public.

I would probably hang on to this idea until the company gets sold.

Risks

Even with investors like KKR and John Goff, an investment idea can fail to work out for any number of reasons. However, there is a safety factor here in that the debt ratio is within a reasonable range. Companies with relatively low debt rarely get into serious trouble. There is every chance here that with the project improvements to acquired properties, that debt ratio will decline even if no money was used to repay debt.

Any acquisition can fail to meet expectations. On the other side of that both John Goff and KKR have made many acquisitions (to have a whole lot of experience making acquisitions).

KKR is used to building and selling companies. That lowers the risk of fast growth. Fast growth has the risk of losing quality control and cost overruns. So, the experience is needed to minimize some potentially serious issues.

It is extremely difficult to tell much of anything from the financial statements when a company is constantly making acquisitions. But that makes the investor evaluation of management very important to the success of the investment. At this point we are very much dependent upon management representations to tell the progress made. Debt ratings help as well.
